Subsection (a) of section 7123 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow taxpayers to request early referral of unresolved issues to the Internal Revenue Service Office of Appeals. This includes issues from examination or collection divisions, proposed deficiency letters, or notices of deficiency. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows taxpayers to request early referral of unresolved issues to the Internal Revenue Service Office of Appeals. Regulations may limit procedures for cases involving failure to comply with tax laws due to various grounds, excluding issues designated for litigation. SEC. 3. RESTRICTION ON SECRETARIAL AUTHORITY TO DESIGNATE CASES FOR LITIGATION. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 limits the Secretary's authority to designate cases for litigation. The Secretary may designate issues for litigation related to listed transactions, restricting the taxpayer from appealing to the Office of Appeals. Settlement terms may also prevent appeal on such issues. A clerical amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code. The amendments restrict the Secretary's authority to designate cases for litigation and issue designated summons after April 20, 2016. The amendments limit the Secretary's ability to designate cases for litigation and issue designated summons after April 20, 2016. Section 6503(j) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is updated to replace "coordinated examination program" with "coordinated industry case program." Additionally, the process for issuing a summons now requires approval from the Large Business and International Division Commissioner and the Division Counsel of the Office of Chief Counsel. The amendments shift the burden of proof to the Secretary to show that a corporation did not reasonably cooperate with requests for witnesses, documents, meetings, and interviews in court proceedings. Effective from summonses issued after April 20, 2016. SEC. 5. LIMITATION ON ACCESS OF NON-IRS EMPLOYEES TO RETURNS AND RETURN INFORMATION ACQUIRED BY SUMMONS. The amendment to Section 7602 of the Internal Revenue Code limits access to returns and return information to IRS officers and employees only, not to persons authorized under section 6103(n). The effective date of this amendment is upon the enactment of the Act and applies to contracts under section 6103(n) of the Internal Revenue Code.
